content.description: A clean sustained overhanging hand to fist crack
content.protection: May want doubles of hand and fist sized cams
content.location: Left end of the lake in the woods, beach your boat in the lily pads and follow the orange flags, this is the obvious overhanging crack left of the inside corner above a boulder pile. Rappel from bolts at the top.

content.description: Don't want to ruin those new manpris thrutching up off widths? Like clipping bolts yet still find overhanging hand cracks appealing? Climb up the initial hand crack of White lies yellow teeth, step left onto the ledge, then compress and crimp your way up the prow to anchors at the top.
content.location: Start the same as for White lies yellow teeth. Bolt anchor at the top.

content.description:
The crux is low over a ledge and involves a left hand reach to gain a crack guarded by flexy flakes. 

  Rappel from trees.
content.location: Follow the orange flags up hill to the first cliff band running perpendicular to the trail, off to the right. There is a shelf 1/2 way up on the left end of the face. This route is the crack in the middle of the wall.

climbs.name: Reachy Reachy Grabby Grabby Monkey Arms

content.description: Very nice and thoughtful climbing with some face and arete moves mixed in. Secret ledges make this climb a lot of fun and easier than initially thought.
content.protection: Bolts set far back on the top. We needed 30 ft of cordelette equalized at 15 feet each side to make an anchor. These bolts can be used for both this climb and Pep-O-mint
content.location: 8 feet to the climbers right of Pep-O-mint. Up an somewhat blank looking face with an arete and a mini roof halfway up.

content.description: Great climb with a series of horizontal ledges that makes the first half really pleasant. Last 20 feet the holds become less obvious and climbing becomes slightly harder. Really great face climbing on solid holds.
content.protection: Toprope setup with static rope on two trees for anchors. Two great trees very close together make for an easy setup, 60 feet of static line would be perfect.
content.location: The start is 20 feet right of a tree whose top half is literally pointing towards the ground(Full U-turn). Actual start is almost in the open book corner, 3 feet right of a decent sized tree very close to the cliff.

content.description: If done in its current state this route will not leave you feeling so fresh or so clean. Once clean it will make for an easy route to the top and a decent first trad lead. climb the crack and positive holds to the top.
content.location: Directly left around the corner from "taint no thang" start in a crack on top of a flat boulder.

content.description: Carefully calculate your way up the right side of a knife edged arete through barn door friction cruxes conveniently located above each bolt. The last move to the anchors may be a heart breaker.
content.location: This route is located just to the left of White Lies Yellow Teeth.

content.description:
‘Loopy After Dark’ climbs the obvious crack in a corner on the most northern set of exposed cliffs at Payne lake. There are opportunities for other routes of varying styles, both at this wall and others on the paddle up, though rock quality isn’t the best.

 Start in the center of the left facing corner, climb up through a few small terraces. From here, a series of stemming moves passing small gear brings you up to a slanted ledge with crumbly rock and tricky gear placements. Step right and follow the slightly overhanging hand crack to the top. Watch out for loose rock if topping out.
content.protection: Standard rack, small cams are useful for the first half. Long static if setting a TR. Rappel from trees.
content.location: As it stands, it’s really not worth paddling all the way to these last set of cliffs since this is really the only route to be done and most of the rock in this location isn’t that great in general. However, if you are feeling adventurous and have done everything in the left gully, then this is a nice mini-adventure to take a few hours or so and go do. You also get to check out all of what Payne Lake has to offer on the way down which is worth the paddle alone.Last visible set of cliffs viewed from the launch. Paddle north towards the island and beach your boat on the western shore in front of the giant boulder. Scramble up to the base of the cliff from there. 'Loopy after dark' is the obvious left facing corner with a crack in it. If setting a TR, approaching the top from climbers left is easiest.

content.description: Work your way through hard initial moves and get stuck into a small open book crack with decent laybacking moves and no feet. Get established on a ledge with a full rest and work your way up towards another ledge with an awkward mantle. After this there is still another 10 feet of fun looking climb, but a series of loose death blocks thwarted our efforts. However, as it stands, a wonderful climb with some strange moves.
content.protection: TR anchor with two trees. Good length of static rope necessary. Somewhat dangerous to set up as placing the masterpoint requires hanging out on a sloping ledge with huge fall, place masterpoint through a "V" shaped entrance from the top of the chimney.
content.location: A ways right of "Pure Peter Pan Peanut Better" and a ways left of "Never Ending Math Equation". Obvious 3 sided "chimney".

content.description: Climb up the initial tight hand crack (crux) and up on good holds around the wide crack. Descend by walking climbers right to the bolted anchor above Pep-O-Mint.
content.protection:
Standard rack, The top will take a #5 cam if you feel like you need it.

 Easy TR with two trees. 40-50 of static rope.
content.location: Start 150' left and up hill from 'taint no thang' in a crack with a tree half way up.

content.description: Relatively pleasant crack with positive foot holds, the crux is fighting through the bush at the very top, this can be avoided by traversing left to the inside corner but leads to less protection and significantly harder climbing.
content.protection:
standard rack

 For TR, Two good trees a ways back should do fine. Static rope, maybe 50-60 feet.
content.location: Follow the orange flags up hill this route is in the same corner but 15 feet right of White lies yellow teeth with a pesky bush at the top. Rappel from trees.

content.description:
This area is a ridge of cliffs, some up to 130'-tall, that border the west side of Payne Lake. The ridge continues along the entire length of the lake and there are some bouldering opportunities to the northwest of the main face. 

  This area is mostly undeveloped for climbing, visited only by the occasional hunter, fisherman, and kayaker. There are at least 4 large-ish cliffs with sheer, overhanging faces. More exploration is necessary, as it seems to be one of the few public-land climbing opportunities in upstate New York outside of the Adirondacks. 

  The rock is similar to that at Eagle Falls. Some is good, some is crumbly, and all of it is brittle. New routes will require cleaning and plucking. Trad protection is sucpect due to the brittle nature of the rock, so take care. 

  If you're at all nearby here please check this rock out and add some comments or routes to the site so that this unknown area can get a little attention. 

  On the lakeside cliffs, there is poison ivy *everywhere*, so watch out!
